Draw the first line (line\\_1) with the following end points: * Start Point: [0.0, 0.0] * End Point: [0.75, 0.0] 2. Draw the second line (line\\_2) with the following end points: * Start Point: [0.75, 0.0] * End Point: [0.75, 0.5794] 3. Draw the third line (line\\_3) with the following end points: * Start Point: [0.75, 0.5794] * End Point: [0.0, 0.5794] 4. Draw the fourth line (line\\_4) with the following end points: * Start Point: [0.0, 0.5794] * End Point: [0.0, 0.0] The aforementioned lines form the border of the first face (face\\_1) containing loop\\_1. Make sure that all curve endpoints are connected smoothly, and the loop is closed. Step 3: Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch Transform the 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the previously defined coordinate system. You can do this by applying the relevant euler angle rotations and translation vector to the sketch plane. Step 4: Extrude the 2D sketch into a 3D model Extrude the 2D sketch along the normal direction creating a 3D model with the following dimensions: * Extrusion Depth Towards Normal: 0.4243 * Extrusion Depth Opposite Normal: 0.0 * Sketch Scale: 0.75 This extrusion constitutes the creation of a three-dimensional rectangular prism, with a flat top and bottom, equal side lengths, and a height equal to half of the side length. These instructions outline the creation of part\\_1. The final step involves generating a new solid body using "NewBodyFeatureOperation". The completed part\\_1 model can now be 3D printed or incorporated into a CAD assembly for further processing.</description>
